The date when a mountain glacier in Switzerland was monitored and predicted to collapse, enabling the evacuation of the village of Blatten.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which the world has experienced a surge in extreme weather events, such as floods and wildfires, prompting the UN's call for improved early-warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of such deaths occurring in developing countries over the past 50 years.
The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) reports that over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years.

While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52 in the past decade), half of 62 assessed countries have only basic capacity, and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is worst in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries launching functioning websites and issuing standardized alerts.
The WMO emphasizes that early warning systems enable early action and empower communities to respond to disasters.
Extreme weather events have intensified globally in 2025, including massive flooding in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US.
Swiss scientists used glacier monitoring to predict a collapse in May 2025, allowing evacuation of the village of Blatten, illustrating the real-world value of early-warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), under the UN, has urged global action to address the critical gap in early-warning systems for extreme weather events. Despite progress in monitoring over the past decade, nearly half of countries still lack adequate systems, with devastating consequences—disaster-related deaths being six times higher in countries without such systems. The article highlights real-world events in 2025, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, all underscoring the urgency of climate-driven disasters. A key example is the Swiss village of Blatten, where glacier monitoring in May 2025 allowed for timely evacuation, demonstrating the life-saving potential of early warnings. The WMO emphasizes that early warning is not just about alerts but about enabling early action to protect lives and infrastructure, especially in vulnerable and conflict-affected regions, and calls for global investment and coordination to close the monitoring gap.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
